tldr_summary.summary:
**TLDR: April 30, 2025 Market Summary**  

**🔥 Key Market Moves**  
- **Tech earnings save the day**: Meta (+6% after-hours) and Microsoft (+7% after-hours) beat Q1 estimates, boosting Nasdaq/S&P 500 futures despite earlier GDP-driven declines[1][2].  
- **GDP shock**: US economy shrank 0.3% in Q1 (vs 0.4% growth forecast), triggering midday selloffs before late tech-led recovery[1][2].  
- **Index streaks**: S&P 500 (+0.15%) and Dow (+0.35%) extended winning streaks to 7 days, showcasing market resilience[1].  

**📉 Macro Watch**  
- **Recession risks rise**: Consumer confidence plunged 12.5 points (April) while Leading Economic Index fell 0.7% (March)[1].  
- **Labor silver lining**: Private sector added 325K jobs in Jan-Feb 2025, though payroll growth slowed to 152K/month in Q1[1].  

**🚨 Critical Developments**  
- **Trade war tremors**: America Movil’s Mexico/Brazil user losses (-1.4M) highlight emerging market strain from US tariff threats[1].  
- **Commodity standstill**: Oil/gold markets paused ahead of Thursday’s EIA petroleum report and manufacturing data[1].  

**🔍 What’s Next**  
- **May 1 highlights**: ISM Manufacturing Index and 10-Year Note Auction could dictate short-term sentiment[1].  
- **Earnings spotlight**: Apple/Amazon results (Thursday) to test whether tech can sustain GDP-defying rally[1].  

**The Bottom Line**: Markets shrugged off recession signals through tech strength, but tariff impacts and slowing growth keep volatility elevated. Watch today’s manufacturing data for confirmation of economic trajectory.

news_items.headline: Tech Earnings from Meta and Microsoft Drive After-Hours Rally
news_items.summary: Meta Platforms and Microsoft reported better-than-expected Q1 earnings, with Meta's EPS at $6.43 (vs. $5.25 expected) and revenue of $42.3B (vs. $41.3B expected). Microsoft also surpassed earnings estimates, boosting investor sentiment.
news_items.impact: Nasdaq futures rose 1.3% in after-hours trading, while S&P 500 and Dow futures gained 0.8% and 0.4%, respectively, offsetting earlier declines during the regular session.
news_items.source: Late rally propels Dow, S&P 500 to slight gains - YouTube [1]

news_items.headline: US Q1 GDP Contracts 0.3%, Sparking Recession Fears
news_items.summary: The US economy shrank at a 0.3% annualized rate in Q1 2025, reversing from 2.4% growth in Q4 2024. The decline was driven by a 41% surge in imports (linked to tariff pre-empting) and reduced consumer/government spending.
news_items.impact: The Dow fell 281 points (-0.7%), S&P 500 dropped 1%, and Nasdaq slid 1.4% during regular trading as investors priced in heightened recession risks.

news_items.headline: America Movil Profit Misses Estimates Amid Mexico Slowdown
news_items.summary: Carlos Slim's America Movil reported Q1 net income of 18.7B pesos ($953M), below estimates, as 1.4M prepaid users disconnected in Mexico and Brazil due to economic strains exacerbated by US tariff threats.
news_items.impact: Shares fell 1.8% in Mexican trading before paring losses, reflecting broader concerns about emerging market stability and US trade policy impacts.

indices.name: S&P 500
indices.summary: Recovered from intraday lows to close slightly higher despite GDP contraction fears, marking its seventh straight day of gains. Driven by tech earnings resilience.

indices.name: Dow Jones Industrial Average
indices.summary: Gained 141 points as investors bought dips in blue-chip stocks, shrugging off recession concerns tied to Trump-era tariff impacts.

indices.name: Nasdaq Composite
indices.summary: Moderately declined despite after-hours rallies in Microsoft (+7%) and Meta (+6%), reflecting sector rotation ahead of Apple/Amazon earnings.

data.overall_summary: Equities demonstrated remarkable resilience with S&P 500 and Dow extending win streaks despite Q1 GDP contraction (-0.3%), as investors focused on strong tech earnings and potential tariff policy shifts. Commodities and crypto lacked fresh data, while markets awaited Thursday's earnings (Apple/Amazon) and economic reports to confirm whether the GDP dip was tariff-driven anomaly or sustained slowdown.

economic_conditions.employment: Payroll job growth slowed to 152,000 average monthly in Q1 2025; private sector added 325,000 jobs in first two months of 2025

data.global_outlook: The US economy shows moderating growth amid trade policy uncertainties, with risks of supply chain disruptions and inflationary pressures from potential tariffs. Data for EU, China, and Sweden are unavailable in provided sources, limiting a comprehensive global assessment.

stocks.overall_summary: Fundamental outlook: Bullish. Technical analysis: Short-term bullish reversal after earnings-driven 6% after-hours gain. Recent news: Q3 FY2025 earnings exceeded expectations with $70.07B revenue (+13% YoY) and $25.82B net profit, driven by 21% Intelligent Cloud growth[1].
